questions.text: Following the delivery of a healthy baby boy, his COVID positive mother slipped into ARDS and passed away. The relatives have arranged a breast milk donor and wish to feed the baby using the device shown in the image.  In newborns of which gestational age, would you recommend this as a method of primary feeding?
questions.solution:
The given image shows paladai. It can be used as a primary feeding method during routine feeding in neonates born at gestational age 32-34 weeks only. Sick mothers or mothers with contraindications to breastfeeding can feed their child using paladai. The milk can either be expressed breastmilk or they can resort to using undiluted cow milk or formula feeds.

28-32 weeks

 Oro-gastric/ Nasogastric tube feeding with occasional spoon/ paladai feeding

>34 weeks Mature sucking pattern. More coordination between breathing and swallowing Breastfeeding

questions.solution:

questions.solution:
The image shows Metzenbaum scissors. It is used to cut dissect and cut tissues such as the peritoneum and adhesions. It is similar to Mayo scissors in that the ends are the same on both scissor halves, but its handles are longer and its middle section is slightly narrower.

The given image shows the Metzenbaum scissors:

 

Other options:

Option A- Umbilical cord scissors are used to cut the umbilical cord soon after delivery.

 

Option C- Episiotomy scissor is bent on the edge. It has a blunt tup that goes inside the vagina. It is used to perform episiotomy during delivery.

questions.text: The equipment shown below is used for the sterilization of all of the following except:
questions.solution:
The given image shows an autoclave.  It is not used to sterilize endoscopes because most of them are heat-sensitive. 

Autoclaving is a method of heat sterilization using steam under pressure. The temperature is kept between 108oC to 147oC. It is used to sterilize linen, instruments, laboratory ware, media, pharmaceutical products, aqueous solutions, surgical instruments, cardiac catheters, and implants.

Endoscopes are cleaned using liquid chemical sterilizing agents such as orthophthaldehyde as it has bactericidal properties and is quick, safe and effective.`

Other equipments used in sterilization include:

Hot air oven- The objects undergo a holding period of 160oC for two hours to sterilize glassware, forceps, scissors, scalpels, swabs, and some pharmaceutical products such as liquid paraffin, dusting powder.

 

UV sterilization: Ultraviolet radiation is used to disinfect enclosed areas mainly biosafety cabinets in laboratories, operation theatres, and laboratories. The given image shows UV sterilization in a biosafety cabinet.

 

Incineration : Terminal sterilisation for destroying biomedical waste such as human anatomical waste and plastics such as PVC and polythene.

questions.text: Identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
The image shows Luedde's exophthalmometer used to measure proptosis.

Exophthalmometry measures protrusion of the apex of the cornea from the outer orbital margin (with the eyes looking straight ahead).

An absolute protrusion of >20 mm or a difference of >2 mm between the two eyes is labeled as proptosis.

Instruments used to measure proptosis:

  • Luedde exophthalmometer
  • Hertel’s exophthalmometer
  • Naugle Exophthalmometer 

Hertel's exophthalmometer (image below): The most commonly used instrument. It measures both eyes simultaneously.


Luedde’s exophthalmometer (image below): The simplest instrument to measure proptosis

 

Naugle Exophthalmometer (image below): This is a superior and inferior orbital rim-based instrument. Useful in lateral orbital wall fracture or surgery.

Maddox wing test is used to measure heterophoria for near vision. The following instrument is used for this test.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man undergoes pancreatic necrosectomy. The surgeon decides to place abdominal drains following the procedure. Which of the given suture materials is preferred for securing the drain externally?
questions.solution:
Silk sutures are commonly used to secure external drains.

Silk is a blue/black-colored, multifilament, natural, braided, and non-absorbable suture material derived from the cocoon of the silkworm larva. Fibrous encapsulation of the suture occurs in 2 to 3 weeks, and it is absorbed slowly over 1 to 2 years.

It can be used for ligation and suturing when long-term tissue support is necessary. It can also be used for skin closure; however, there is an increased risk of infection and tissue reaction. It can be used for securing drains externally. Silk is not suitable for use with a vascular prosthesis or in tissues requiring prolonged approximation under stress. 


Other options:

Option A: Polydioxanone is a delayed absorbable suture material with a longer wound support period.

Option B: Monocryl (Polygylcaprone) is an absorbable suture material and is used in the subcuticular suturing in the skin. 

Option D: Polypropylene is a monofilament, non-absorbable suture material. It is one of the best sutures for vascular anastomosis.  It is used in plastic surgery, cardiovascular surgery, hernia repair, ophthalmic surgery, and general surgical subcuticular skin closure. Polypropylene mesh is used for hernia repair.

questions.text: In your community medicine practicals, you are given an apparatus as shown in the image given below. Which of the following statements regarding the apparatus is true?

choices.text: The indicator used is bromocresol purple
It is used to estimate free chlorine levels
It is used to estimate combined chlorine levels

questions.solution:
The image given is that of a Horrock's apparatus. The indicator used in Horrock's apparatus is starch iodide.

Horrock's apparatus contains 6 white cups (200 ml each), 1 black cup with a circular mark, 2 metal spoons with 2 grams of bleaching powder in each, 7 glass stirring rods, 1 special pipette and 2 droppers. It is not usful in measuring free and combined chlorine. It estimates the chlorine demand of water and is used to calculate the amount of bleaching powder used to disinfect the well.

Related Pearl: Horrock’s Apparatus

  • Horrock’s Apparatus is used to estimate the chlorine demand of water.
  • This is widely used in the disinfection of wells to find out how much bleaching powder is required.
  • Contents of this water-testing apparatus:
    • 6 white cups of 200 ml each and one black cup with a circular mark
    • 2 metal spoons (each holds 2g of bleaching powder)
    • 7 glass stirring rods and 1 special pipette
    • Two droppers
    • Starch-iodide indicator solution
  • Procedure:
    • Use 2g of bleaching powder to create a thin paste in the black cup. It is now called the Chlorine stock solution.
    • The six white cups are filled with the water to be tested
    • Add one drop of the stock solution to the 1st cup, two drops to the 2nd cup, three drops to the 3rd cup, and so on till adding six drops to the 6th cup.
    • Stir the cups and wait for half an hour.
    • Add 3 drops of starch-iodide indicator to each cup
    • Development of blue color in the apparatus indicates free residual chlorine. 
    • The first cup which develops this color gives an estimate of the amount of bleaching powder needed to disinfect 455 Litres of the sample water.
  • Chlorine demand or the dose of bleaching powder required is given by (n x 2) g for 455 liters of water, i.e., (n x 2) g of bleaching powder is required to disinfect 455 liters of water. Here, n represents the position of the cup (1, 2, 3, etc.) that was first to show a distinct blue color.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presented with progressive blurred vision, photophobia, and pain in the right eye. On examination, there was conjunctival redness, a mid-dilated pupil, and a shallow anterior chamber in the right eye. A procedure incorporates the following device to aid drainage and treat this condition. Identify the device.
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette points to a diagnosis of glaucoma and the device used is an Ex-Press glaucoma implant (mini shunt).

It is a minimally invasive glaucoma surgery (MIGS) to increase aqueous drainage.

Ex-Press glaucoma implant (mini shunt), is a small stainless steel device. It is inserted under a scleral flap during a modified trabeculectomy. Mitomycin c might be used to prevent scarring. Complications such as hypotony are lower as compared to standard trabeculectomy.

 

Glaucoma drainage devices: They are devices that allow aqueous outflow by establishing a communication between the anterior chamber and sub-Tennon's space/sub-conjunctival space. 

The commonly used devices are as follows:

  • Shunts using episcleral explants

    • Ahmed glaucoma valve: A valved implant consisting of a silicone tube connected to a silicone sheet valve held together in a polypropylene body. It has a venturi valve mechanism that allows for an immediate decrease in IOP and reduced post-operative complications such as hypotony. 

    • Molteno implant: One or two polypropylene plates connected to a silicone tube. It has a larger surface area and provides long-term IOP reduction. However, risk of post-operative hypotony is high. 

    • Baerveldt implant: Large silicone plate connected to a silicone tube. It is easy to modify, flexible, and easy to implant. However, it is a bulky device and post-operative hypotony and scar deformation are associated risks. 

  • Mini-shunts 

    • Ex-Press Mini-Shunt

    • iStent®: It is a hooked titanium tube inserted into the Schlemm canal via the trabecular meshwork. More than one istent can be implanted a the same time for better control of the intraocular pressure.

The images below show the Ahmed and Molteno implants respectively.

questions.text: Identify the instrument given below, and choose the false statement regarding the procedure done using it.

choices.text: It is performed for the diagnosis and staging of lymphoma.
Postoperative bleeding is a common complication.

questions.solution:
The image shows a bone marrow biopsy needle. Thrombocytopenia is not an absolute contraindication for bone marrow biopsy. If the platelet count falls below 20,000 cells/μL, or if clinically warranted, platelet transfusion is performed before the procedure.

Indications:

  • Evaluation of unexplained anemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and pancytopenia
  • Evaluation of multiple myeloma, lymphoma, and myelodysplastic syndrome
  • Diagnosis and staging of lymphoma or solid tumors
  • Diagnosis and evaluation of plasma cell disorders and leukemias
  • Evaluation of infections such as histoplasmosis, leishmaniasis, cryptococcosis, and Q fever
  • Evaluation of fever of unknown origin

Contraindications: 

  • Severe hemophilia
  • Severe disseminated intravascular coagulopathy
  • Severe bleeding disorders

Postoperative bleeding is a common complication. It is due to the high vascularity of the sampled tissue. Manual pressure and pressure bandaging can be done until the bleeding subsides.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female patient is undergoing a vaginal hysterectomy. The instrument given below is used to retract the posterior vaginal wall. Identify the given instrument.
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the image is the Auvard speculum.

It is a self-retaining heavy retractor provided with a heavy metal ball. It is used in vaginal hysterectomy to retract the posterior vaginal wall. A channel is provided in the handle to collect the blood and drain it. An image of the Auvard speculum is given below.

 

Option B - Cusco's speculum is a bivalve self-retaining speculum, ideal for out-patient use. It allows satisfactory inspection of the cervix, obtaining a Pap smear, and collection of the vaginal discharge from the posterior fornix. An image of Cusco's speculum is given below:

 

Option C -The Sims’ vaginal speculum with an anterior vaginal wall retractor can be used for examination of the cervix. This is used to expose the cervix prior to cervical dilatation. It is used for the assessment of the vaginal wall for cystocele and rectocele. 

 

Option D- Doyen's retractor is used to retract the abdominal wall as well as the bladder to facilitate better exposure of the lower uterine segment during cesarian operation.

The image below shows Doyen's retractor. 

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the procedure done with the needle shown below?

choices.text: Used in the therapeutic management of psuedotumor cerebri

questions.solution:
The above image shows a lumbar puncture needle. Coagulopathy is a contraindication for this procedure.

Lumbar puncture is preferably performed in the lateral recumbent position. (Option A) The lateral recumbent position allows more accurate measurement of the opening pressure, thus they are preferred over the upright position. Using sterile techniques, after administering a local anesthetic, the interspace between L3-L4/L4-L5 is pierced and the needle is inserted in a cephalad direction, towards the umbilicus. (Option C)

Indications of lumbar puncture include suspicion of meningitis, suspicion of subarachnoid hemorrhage, and therapeutic relief of pseudotumor cerebri. (Option B)

Contraindications for lumbar puncture include:

  • Thrombocytopenia or other bleeding diatheses (including ongoing anticoagulant therapy).
  • Possible raised intracranial pressure.
  • Suspected spinal epidural abscess.
  • Skin infection over the needle entry site.

The complications of lumbar puncture include post-spinal puncture headache, bloody tap, infection, hemorrhage, post-dural puncture cerebral herniation.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy had fever and cough for 1 week, following which he developed a severe earache, decreased hearing, and a feeling of stuffiness in his left ear. Otoscopy revealed a bulging, erythematous tympanic membrane. He was managed with antibiotics. On follow-up after 12 weeks, persistent effusion was noted, and it was managed with the procedure shown below. Identify the instrument used in the procedure.
questions.solution:
The case described with fever, earache, erythematous, and bulging tympanic membrane points to a diagnosis of acute suppurative otitis media (ASOM), which is treated by antibiotics and incision of the tympanic membrane using a myringotome (myringotomy).

Treatment is with antibiotics, and supportive therapy like nasal decongestants, antipyretics, ear toilet, and dry heat. Myringotomy is the incision of the tympanic membrane using a sharp myringotome, to evacuate pus. It is indicated in ASOM when:

  • The tympanic membrane is bulging with severe pain
  • Persistent conductive hearing loss despite antibiotics
  • Persistent effusion beyond 12 weeks.
  • Complications like facial paralysis, labyrinthitis, or meningitis with bulging tympanic membrane arise.
  • Recurrent acute otitis media

ASOM is an acute inflammation of the middle ear by pyogenic organisms. The disease usually follows a viral upper respiratory tract infection and occurs in the following stages:

1. Stage of tubal occlusion: Eustachian tube gets blocked with retraction of the tympanic membrane and effusion in the middle ear. However, fluid may not be clinically visible. Patients present with mild deafness and earache, but no fever. Tuning fork tests show conductive deafness.

2. Stage of presuppuration: Prolonged tubal occlusion leads to pyogenic infection of the tympanic cavity. The tympanic membrane becomes congested with a leash of blood vessels along the handle of the malleus and at the periphery of the tympanic membrane (cart-wheel appearance). Tuning fork tests show conductive hearing loss. Patients present with throbbing earache, deafness, tinnitus, and fever.

3. Stage of suppuration: Formation of pus in the middle ear, with bulging tympanic membrane and loss of landmarks. A yellow spot may be seen where a rupture might occur. Tenderness may be elicited over the mastoid antrum. Patients present with severe earache, increasing deafness and fever of 102–103 °F, vomiting, and even convulsions.

4. Stage of resolution: The tympanic membrane ruptures with the release of pus and symptoms subside. A small perforation is seen in the anteroinferior quadrant of pars tensa. 

5. Stage of complications: Acute mastoiditis, subperiosteal abscess, facial paralysis, labyrinthitis, petrositis, extradural abscess, meningitis, brain abscess, or lateral sinus thrombophlebitis may develop.

Other options:

Option A: Lempert’s curette (scoop) is used in mastoid surgery for the removal of bony septa and granulations.

Option B: Tilley Lichtwitz trocar and cannula are used for proof punctures (antral lavage). Puncture using the trocar is done in the inferior meatus because this site is easily accessible and safe.

Option D: MacEwen’s curette is used in mastoid surgery to explore the air cells using one end and to curette the intervening septa and granulations with the other.

Related Pearl: Myringotomy

Indications:
  • Acute suppurative otitis media:
    • Severe earache with the bulging tympanic membrane.
    • Incomplete resolution with opaque drum and persistent conductive deafness.
    • Complications of acute otitis media,e.g.facialparalysis, labyrinthitis or meningitis with the bulging tympanic membrane.
  • Serous otitis media.
  • Aero-otitis media (to drain fluid and “unlock” the eustachian tube).
  • Atelectatic ear (grommet is often inserted for long-term aeration).

Contraindication: Suspected intratympanic glomus tumor.

Incisions: 

  • In acute suppurative otitis media, a circumferential incision is made in the posteroinferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane, midway between the handle of malleus and tympanic annulus, avoiding injury to the incudostapedial joint.
  • In serous otitis media, a small radial incision is given in the anteroinferior quadrant and all the effusion is sucked out.

Complications:

  • Injury to incudostapedial joint or stapes.
  • Injury to jugular bulb with profuse bleeding, if jugular bulb is high and floor of the middle ear dehiscent.
  • Middle ear infection.

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
The image shows Ewald’s tube used in the gastric lavage.

Gastric lavage has been used to manage toxic ingestions for a long time. It is indicated in unprotected airway, seizures, and the need for urgent removal of toxic substances. 

Contraindications for this procedure include insignificant ingestions, prolonged time since ingestion, and caustic poisoning. Activated charcoal is usually given after lavage.

Complications include nasal trauma, esophageal perforation, tracheal intubation, aspiration, and hypothermia. 

The following image shows Ewald's tube.

 

Other options-

Option A: Ryle's tube (nasogastric tube) is indicated in intestinal obstruction and nutritional support. 

 

Option C- Sengstaken Blakemore tube is used for balloon tamponade in case of hemorrhage due to esophageal varices. 

 

Option D- Kehr's T tube is used to stent and drain the bile duct after choledochotomy.

questions.text: The brace shown below is used for
questions.solution:
The given image shows the anterior spinal hyperextension brace. A dorso-lumbar injury should be managed with an ASH brace (anterior spinal hyperextension brace) following surgery.  A hyperextension brace will take the pressure off the weak vertebrae and limit forward bending.

Other options:

Scoliosis and kyphosis can be managed with the Milwaukee brace. Also known as a cervico-thoraco-lumbosacral orthosis or CTLSO, it is a back brace used in the treatment of spinal curvatures (such as scoliosis or kyphosis) in children. It is less commonly used nowadays due to the convenience of modern braces. It is still used for scoliosis with curves in the high thoracic and cervical spine.

The image shown below is the Milwaukee brace.

 

Scoliosis is managed most commonly with the Boston brace which is a type of thoracic-lumbar-sacral-orthosis (TLSO brace).

The image given below shows the Boston brace:

 

The sterno-occipital mandibular immobilization (SOMI) brace is used for cervical spine injury. It may also be used as a recovery aid following cervical spine surgery.

questions.text: The instrument shown below will be least useful for examining patients with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a proctoscope. It is not used for examining patients with anal fissures. 

Due to pain, digital rectal examination and anoscopy are not performed immediately in an acute anal fissure. It is reserved for later when the symptoms resolve or the patient is in the operating room.

Proctoscopy is indicated in patients with the following:

  • Rectal bleeding
  • Change in bowel habit, especially recurring attacks of diarrhea
  • Pain or difficulty in defecation
  • Lesions around the anal opening - abscesses, fistulae, discharge, ulcers, external hemorrhoids
  • Rectal prolapse.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with a fracture of the femur. The surgeon used the instrument shown below for internal fixation of her fracture. Identify the instrument?
questions.solution:
The Kuntscher's cloverleaf intra-medullary nail, also known as the K-nail can be used for internal fixation of femoral fractures and it is represented by the image.

Kuntscher's cloverleaf intra-medullary nail (K nail) - 

  • It is used for the treatment of femoral fractures.
  • It is based on the concept of three-point fixation i.e., at either end and at the isthmus.
  • The eye at the end of the nail is useful while removing it.
  • Cloverleaf shape on the cross-section provides good rotational stability.

 

Other options

Option B: Square nail -  Used for the management of fractures of forearm bones

 

Option C: Interlocking nails (image shown below) are used in the management of fractures of the femoral and tibial shafts.

 

Option D: Steinmann's Pin- It is a stout, straight steel rod of diameter ranging from 3 to 6 mm. It is used for skeletal traction— common sites being upper end of the tibia, supracondylar region of the femur, and calcaneum. Bohler’s stirrup is used for holding Steinmann pin in skeletal traction.

Related Pearl: Orthopedic Instruments

questions.text: An intern in the surgery department uses the following instrument to catheterize a patient. What is the size of the catheter used by him?
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the above image is Foley's catheter. The presence of a white-colored ring in the balloon port indicates its size as 12 F.

Indications of catheterization include:

  • Providing relief in acute and chronic urinary retention
  • Obtaining urine for analysis
  • Dilatation of urethral strictures
  • Performing continuous bladder infusion
  • Maintaining the bladder hygiene of an immobile patient
  • Decompression of a neurogenic bladder

Other options:

Option A: 14 F Foley's catheter has a green ring in the balloon port.

Option B: 16 F Foley's catheter has an orange ring in the balloon port. 

Option D: 18 F Foley's catheter has a red ring in the balloon port.

The image below shows Foley's catheters with different colored rings in the balloon ports.

Related Pearl: Foley's Catheter

A Foley catheter is a thin, sterile tube inserted into the bladder to drain urine. Because it can be left in place in the bladder for a period of time, it is also called an indwelling catheter.

French scale corresponds to the outer diameter in millimetres, and 1Fr is 0.3 mm in diameter.

Fr. size = 3 x d, where d is the outer diameter in mm. 

A 18 Fr. catheter will have a circumference of approximately 18 mm and a diameter of 6 mm. 

Note:

Colour of the foleys is the colour at the baloon port as shown in the figure below

questions.text: As an ENT resident, you are assisting in the reduction of a nasal bone fracture. Which of the following instruments would you use?
questions.solution:
Walsham forceps (Image 2) is used to reduce a nasal bone fracture.

Asch forceps is mainly used to reduce nasal septum fracture.

 

Option A: Luc’s forceps is used in Caldwell Luc operation, submucous resection, and polypectomy.

 

Option C: Tilley’s forceps is used in nasal packing in the epistaxis.

 

Option D: Citelli’s forceps is used for bone punch.
